title: Shyam K. Sharma @ Shyam Sunder Sharma vs State (Local Self) & Ors on 25 September, 2012
doc:
Shyam K. Sharma @ Shyam Sunder Sharma vs State (Local Self) & Ors on 25 September, 2012

Bench: Arun Mishra, Sangeet Lodha

                                      1

     IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE FOR RAJASTHAN AT JODHPUR

                                 JUDGMENT

     1.    Shyam Kumar Sharma @ Shyam Sunder Sharma vs. State of
          Rajasthan & Ors.
          [D.B.CIVIL SPECIAL APPEAL(W) NO. 755/12]


     2. Shyam Kumar Sharma @ Shyam Sunder Sharma vs. State of
        Rajasthan & Ors.
         [D.B.CIVIL SPECIAL APPEAL(W) NO. 789/12]

                      Date of Judgment : 25.09.2012



             HON'BLE THE CHIEF JUSTICE MR.ARUN MISHRA
                 HON'BLE MR.JUSTICE SANGEET LODHA


Dr.P.S.Bhati, for the appellant.
Mr. V.D.Dadhich, for caveator-Municipal Board,Nagaur.


BY THE COURT: ( PER HON'BLE MR.SANGEET LODHA,J.)

1. These intra-court appeals are directed against order dated 4.6.12 of learned Single Judge of this court, whereby two writ petitions preferred by the appellant; one seeking direction to the respondent- Municipal Board, Nagaur ('the Board") for executing lease deed in favour of the appellant of the disputed land for construction of Cinema Hall and another questioning the Notice Inviting Tender(NIT) dated 10.5.11 issued by the respondent-Board for award of contract of various constructions to be raised for establishing Ecological Park & Water Pond Project on the said land, stand dismissed.

2

2. The Special Appeal No.789/12 filed by the appellant is time barred by 3 days, however, it is not accompanied by an application u/s 5 of Limitation Act and therefore, it deserves to be dismissed as barred by limitation. The Special Appeal No.755/12 is time barred by 2 days, which is accompanied by an application(IA No.11/12) u/s 5 of the Limitation Act. The application is not opposed by the counsel appearing for the caveator-respondent. For the reasons stated in the application, we are satisfied that the appellant was prevented from filing the appeal within limitation for sufficient cause. Accordingly, the application (IA No.11/12) is allowed. The delay in filing the appeal is condoned.

3. Since, both the Special Appeals arise out of a common order passed by the learned Single Judge and therefore, the same were taken up for consideration together and are being disposed of by this common judgment.

4. The brief facts of the case are that the respondent-Board issued a public notice dated 12.4.84 inviting tenders for letting out the land situated near Makan Gate, in the east of Nangani Piao, Nagaur ('disputed land') on annual rent for a period of 15 years. The appellant quoted market value of the disputed land as Rs.2.80 lacs and accordingly, offered annual rent @ Rs.2,800/- per annum. As per the notice issued, the allotment of the disputed land was subject to sanction by the Deputy Town Planner. Admittedly, the Senior Town Planner, Bikaner Zone, Bikaner granted sanction vide communication 3 dated 10.9.84 inter alia in terms that the sale of the disputed land shall be made in conformity with the provisions of Rajasthan Municipalities (Disposal of Urban Lands) Rules, 1974('Rules of 1974'). Since, the disputed land was being allotted for construction of Cinema therefore, the matter was sent to the State Government for approval. Thereafter, no further steps were taken either by the Municipal Board, the State Government or by the appellant for more than 13 years. However, at a belated stage, vide communication dated 24.2.97, the respondent-Board sent the matter to the Director, Local Bodies, for approval and in response thereto, the Director specifically conveyed that the disputed land could be disposed of in terms of Rule 15(3) of the Rules of 1974.

5. It is pertinent to note that as per provisions of Rule 15(3)(c) of the Rules of 1974, the procedure for letting out the land for Cinemas on annual rental basis is wholly abandoned yet, the Municipal Board moved the matter to the Deputy Minister, Urban Development and Local Self Department, Government of Rajasthan vide letter dated 12.2.98 seeking permission for disposal of the disputed land in favour of the appellant pursuant to notification dated 24.7.71. The Deputy Minister granted approval observing that complete arrears of rent be deposited and the lease deed may be executed and thereafter, possession of the land should be handed over and compliance report be submitted within a period of one week. In these circumstances, the respondent-Board issued demand notice of Rs.42,000/- towards rent payable, from 1984 to 4 February, 1999, which was deposited by the appellant on 19.5.99 much after expiry of the time given by the Deputy Minister vide communication dated 12.2.98. The appellant also tried to deposit the rent from February,1999 vide demand draft of Rs.63,420/- on 19.11.10, which was not encashed by the respondent-Board. Indisputably, the lease deed was never executed in favour of the appellant and later, the respondent-Board took a decision to use the disputed land for developing 'Ecological Park & Water Pond' and for execution of such plan, a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was also entered into between MDH Masalawala and the respondent-Board.

6. Since, no steps were taken by the respondent-Board for execution of the lease deed in favour of the appellant therefore, the appellant preferred a writ petition being No.12056/10 before this court with the prayer for restraining the respondents from carrying out any work over the disputed land and further seeking direction to execute lease deed in his favour. During the pendency of the writ petition preferred by the appellant as aforesaid, vide letter dated 17.1.11, the respondent-Board offered the appellant allotment of an alternate land in lieu of the disputed land. In this view of the matter, learned Single Judge of this court vide order dated 19.1.11 observed that the appellant herein may approach the Executive Officer, who will take final decision within one month for allotment of alternate land to the appellant. However, the respondent-Board in its meeting held on 24.1.11 unanimously resolved 5 not to allot any alternate land to the appellant and issued NIT dated 10.5.11 inviting tenders for award of the contract for various constructions to be raised for establishment of Ecological Park & Water Pond. In these circumstances, the appellant preferred yet another writ petition No.5959/11 with the prayer as aforesaid.

7. After due consideration of the rival submissions, both the writ petitions have been dismissed by the learned Single Judge vide order impugned dated 4.6.12. Hence, these intra-court appeals.

8. Learned Single Judge taking note of the provisions of Rule 15 of the Rules of 1974 arrived at a categorical finding that the allotments of the land for Hotels & Cinema could be made on the basis of 99 years lease hold rights by way of public auction in the manner prescribed in Annexure A attached to the Rules of 1974. Learned Single Judge observed that Rule 15(3) of the Rules of 1974 clearly provides that the procedure for letting out the land for cinemas on annual rental basis is wholly abandoned and therefore, the process initiated by the Board for letting out the land for cinema purposes could not have been carried out as conveyed by the Senior Town Planner vide communication dated 19.9.84. That apart, the learned Single Judge found that as per government order dated 24.7.71 for determining the valuation of the land, yearly rent was to be fixed @ 10% of the market value of the subject land for cinema purpose which in the instant case comes to Rs.28,000/- per annum. However, as per the appellant's bid offer based 6 on his own assessment of the value of the disputed land at the rate of Rs.2.80 lacs, the amount of rent comes to Rs.2,800/- per annum only which was apparently not in conformity with the government order dated 24.7.71. Precisely, the learned Single Judge opined that the very process initiated by issuing public notice dated 12.4.84 was not in conformity with the Scheme of the Rules of 1974 and therefore, no legal right of the appellant can be said to have been infringed. Regarding the allotment of alternate land, learned Single Judge observed that admittedly, the procedure provided under the Scheme of Rules was not followed and therefore, there was no occasion available for allotment of any alternative site and there is no provision brought to the notice of the court under the Scheme of Rules of 1974 under which any alternate site could be allotted to the appellant . Lastly, the learned Single Judge observed that noticing the fact that after 13 years of issuance of the public notice dated 12.4.84, no progress was made and after more than a decade, the matter was again put in process, obviously for the reason that the appellant at later stage became Ward Member and held the post of Chairman of Municipal Board during the period from 5.9.97 to 27.8.2000 and by his own influence, the approval from the State Government was sought on 12.2.98.

9. Learned counsel for the appellant contended that the learned Single Judge ought to have appreciated that by the act of the respondents, the hope and desire of the appellant was created and he 7 also complied with the necessary requirement and therefore, it was legitimately expected from the respondent to execute the lease deed of the dispute land in favour of the appellant. Learned counsel submitted that the auction carried out by public notice dated 12.4.84 was not cancelled and therefore, the respondent-Board is under an obligation to accept the bid offered by the appellant. Learned counsel submitted that the directions issued by the Deputy Minister, Local Self Government Department could not have been brushed aside by the respondent- Board. Learned counsel submitted that the Board having accepted the rent, it cannot shirk from its responsibility to execute the sale deed in favour of the appellant.

10. On the other hand, learned counsel appearing for the respondents submitted that the procedure initiated for allotment of the land for cinema purposes on annual rental basis being in violation of the Rules of 1974, no right is created in favour of the appellant on the basis of the offer being made by him pursuant to notice dated 12.4.84. Learned counsel submitted that the land was proposed to be given on annual rental basis and the proceedings initiated having been dropped by the Board and further a decision having been taken to establish Ecological Park & Water Pond over the disputed land, no right is created in favour the appellant to claim allotment of alternate land on annual rental basis, specially when, the provisions of the Rules of 1974 specifically prohibit the allotment of land on annual rental basis. Learned counsel 8 submitted that the findings arrived at by the learned Single Judge are absolutely in conformity with the provisions of Rules of 1974 and the same do not warrant any interference in intra-court appeal jurisdiction.

11. We have considered the rival submissions and perused the material on record.

12. Indisputably, the Rules of 1974 do not envisage allotment of any land for cinemas on annual rental basis rather, by virtue of provisions of Rule 15(3)(c), the procedure for letting out the land for cinemas on annual rental basis stands specifically abandoned. Thus, the proceedings initiated by the respondent-Board in the year 1984 for allotment of the land for cinema on annual rental basis was ex facie illegal. It is pertinent to note that the offer made by the appellant was not accepted by the Board and the matter was sent for approval to the Senior Town Planner as also the State Government. The Senior Town Planner while granting sanction, specifically observed that the land may be sold in conformity with the provisions of the Rules of 1974. It is pertinent to note after a lapse of about more than 13 years when the matter was pursued by the appellant when he was elected as Ward Member and then Chairman of the Board in the year 1997, vide communication dated 30.5.97 addressed to the Executive Officer of the respondent-Board, the Deputy Director, Local Bodies, specifically directed that the matter may be disposed of by the elected board in conformity with Rule 15(3) of the Rules of 1974. Thus, apparently, the 9 proposal for letting out the disputed land for cinema on annual rental value was never approved either by the Senior Town Planner or by the State Government. It appears that the appellant when later elected as Chairman of the respondent-Board exercising his influence got the proposal approved by the Deputy Minister, Local Self Government. In considered opinion of this court, the Deputy Minister had no authority under the law to inter meddle in the matter and direct the respondent- Board to execute the lease deed in favour of the appellant de hors the Rules of 1974. Suffice it to say that no right is created in favour of the appellant on the basis of alleged approval granted by the Deputy Minister and the rent being deposited by the appellant for the period 1984 to 1999 admittedly, after the expiry of the time granted by the Deputy Minister.

13. That apart, the proceedings for allotment of the disputed land being initiated by the respondent-Board in contravention of the provisions of Rules of 1974 and having not been culminated in concluded contract, stands vitiated and the appellant cannot claim any legal right on the basis of offer made by him for allotment of the land on annual rental basis way back in the year 1984. It is settled law that even the highest bidder has no indefeasible right to claim the confirmation of the bid as a matter of right. The authority vested with the power to approve the bid is well within its rights to refuse the confirmation for valid reasons. In this view of the matter, in considered opinion of this court, 10 the view taken by the learned Single Judge regarding the process for allotment initiated being violative of the provisions of the Rules of 1974 and that the same does not create any right in favour of the appellant is absolutely justified .

14. It is pertinent to note that the respondent-Board has already taken the decision to change the user of the disputed land and the respondent Board by adopting a resolution in its meeting have already resolved to establish Ecological Park & Water Pond Project over the said land and sufficient fund has already been invested and NIT has already been issued for award of contract for raising constructions. In this view of the matter, at this belated stage, when no right is created in petitioner's favour, the question of considering his claim for allotment of disputed land on annual rental basis, does not arise.

15. There is yet another aspect of the matter. The process for allotment of the disputed land for cinemas on annual rental basis was initiated way back in the year 1984 which was never culminated in a concluded contract between the appellant and the respondent-Board. At this stage, after a lapse of about 28 years, indisputably, the market value of the disputed land must have increased in alarming proportion. The appellant who did not care to pursue the proposal for allotment for years together has no right whatsoever to claim the said plot for construction of cinema on annual rental basis. As laid down by the Hon'ble Supreme Court in the matter of Rajasthan Housing Board & Anr. 11

v. G.S.Investment & Anr., (2007) 1 SCC, 477, in the matter of auction of the plots by a public body, which are commercial transaction, even if, some defects are found in the ultimate decision resulting in cancellation of the auction, the court should exercise its discretionary power under Article 226 of the Constitution of India with great care and caution and should exercise only in furtherance of the public interest. The court should always keep larger public interest in mind in order to decide whether it should interfere with the decision of the authority. The increase in the cost of the land is also a relevant consideration and therefore, the question of entertaining the appellant's claim at this belated stage shall be obviously against the public interest.

16. For the aforementioned reasons, we are in full agreement with the view taken and the order passed by the learned Single Judge.

17. In the result, the intra-court appeals fail and the same are hereby dismissed. 

           (SANGEET LODHA),J.                                                               (ARUN MISHRA),C.J.




Aditya/-

All corrections made in the judgment/order have been incorporated in the judgment/order being emailed. Aditya Joshi, PS
